IRS Code 532 Meaning

IRS Code 532 typically means the bankruptcy case is marked as closed for the tax module. This page explains when it shows up on transcripts, what it usually signals, and practical next steps. Want to see what clients get? Open the sample report, then run your own transcript when you’re ready.

Try the parser (requires credits)

What is IRS Code 532?

Plain-English definition: IRS Code 532 means the IRS has posted bankruptcy case closure activity to the tax module. It signals the case is marked closed in IRS records, but it does not by itself confirm discharge scope or whether liabilities were eliminated.

Common transcript type
Account Transcript
Usually appears near
Codes 520, 530, 531
Typical context
Bankruptcy timeline status + post-case account posture
Client-friendly summary
"Your bankruptcy case is marked as closed"

When does Code 532 appear?

  • After the case reaches a closure status: Posts when the IRS receives and processes closure information for the bankruptcy case.
  • On specific modules: It can post on certain tax periods that were part of the bankruptcy timeline and not others.
  • After earlier bankruptcy timeline entries: Often appears after Code 520 (filed) and alongside (or after) dismissal/discharge activity depending on what happened in court.

What does Code 532 usually signal?

If this appears alone

The case status is shown as closed in IRS records, but the transcript alone may not tell you whether debts were discharged, dismissed, or modified. Confirm court orders and any related bankruptcy codes before making conclusions about liability relief.

If this appears with Code 806 or 766/768

Refund codes are generally separate from bankruptcy status codes. If you see refund activity around a bankruptcy timeline, focus on sequencing and whether any refund holds or offsets exist. Avoid promising timing until the full account context is clear.

If this appears with Code 290 or 300

Post-case adjustments can occur. If assessment/adjustment entries appear after a case is marked closed, review what changed, why it posted, and whether it affects balances that were expected to be resolved through bankruptcy.

If this appears with Code 570

A hold code indicates there’s still an unresolved action on the account. Treat “case closed” as a status marker, not a guarantee that all IRS actions are complete. Identify the hold reason and confirm whether bankruptcy status affects resolution steps.

What should a tax professional do next?

  1. Confirm context: Read the bankruptcy timeline around the posting date (commonly 520 → 531/530 → 532) and confirm what the court actually entered.
  2. Validate with documents: Match the transcript to court records (final orders, included periods, dismissal vs discharge) before concluding liability impact.
  3. Communicate clearly: Summarize what “closed” means (status) vs what the client cares about (balance and collection posture). Use a written summary alongside your transcript report and reference the complete guide at /resources/how-to-read-irs-transcripts.html.

Example: how this looks in a parsed report

Below is a simplified view of how Code 532 appears in a client-ready transcript report with context:

Bankruptcy status timeline
Code 520 – Bankruptcy or other legal action filed
Date: 03/22/2024
Code 531 – Bankruptcy case dismissed
Date: 06/18/2024
Code 532 – Bankruptcy case closed
Date: 06/18/2024

FAQ

What does IRS Code 532 mean on an IRS transcript?

IRS Code 532 indicates bankruptcy case closure activity has been posted for the tax module. It signals the case is marked as closed in IRS records, but it does not, by itself, confirm which liabilities were discharged or how balances were impacted.

Is “closed” the same as “discharged” for tax debt?

No. “Closed” (Code 532) refers to case status. Discharge is a separate outcome reflected by court orders and related transcript activity. Confirm discharge scope and any non-dischargeable exceptions before concluding liability relief.

What should I verify before telling a client the bankruptcy impact is final?

Verify the court’s final orders, which periods were included, the balance at key dates, and whether transcript activity shows discharge (530), dismissal (531), reopening (534), or post-bankruptcy adjustments. Then document current balance and collection posture.

Can Code 532 appear and later change (reopened)?

Yes. A case can be reopened, and the transcript may later reflect additional bankruptcy status activity. If later codes like 534 (reopened) appear, reassess the timeline and update client guidance.
